head.title: Spiritual Guidance and Smooth Sailing for the Fire Dept.

hedline.hl1: Spiritual Guidance and Smooth Sailing for the Fire Dept.
hedline.hl2: Spiritual Guidance and Smooth Sailing for the Fire Dept.

block.p: Three stout red ships muscled north along the East River. They seemed to grow larger against the backdrop of Governors Island as they approached Pier 17.
Two chaplains, a bagpipe band, fire officials and a throng of tourists awaited their arrival.
Three ships led a procession of eight New York Fire Department boats in a longtime ritual: the blessing of the fleet.
Three stout red ships muscled north along the East River. They seemed to grow larger against the backdrop of Governors Island as they approached Pier 17.
Two chaplains, a bagpipe band, fire officials and a throng of tourists awaited their arrival.
The three ships were leading a procession of eight New York Fire Department boats in a longtime ritual: the blessing of the fleet.
''When a fireboat gets blessed, you have assurance from above that everything is going to be O.K.,'' said Lt. Brian E. Coughlin, 45, of the department's marine division.

Since man first took to the sea, sailors have sought divine protection for their ships. The blessing of the fleet, traditionally bestowed by a Roman Catholic priest, dates at least to 16th-century Spain, and continues today as fishermen set off each season to hunt their dangerous catch.

The Fire Department began its yearly ritual after the 9/11 terror attack. On that day, fireboats evacuated hundreds of people to New Jersey, then pumped in seawater to fight the fires at the World Trade Center's twin towers after a Downtown water main went out.
On Thursday, Flag Day, the blessing provided an excuse for the firefighters of the marine division to get together, listen to music and sell T-shirts to benefit their units.

''I am not a real religious person,'' said Bob Petersen, 48, a firefighter from Long Island who has worked on a boat that patrols the Hudson River for 12 years. ''But I'll take a few minutes to watch the procession and take in the blessing.''
First, the ship Fire Fighter passed, with seven firefighters standing on the port bow, saluting.
Standing against the rail of Pier 17, Msgr. John Delendick, the Roman Catholic priest who is one of eight Fire Department chaplains, read a prayer.
Holding his right hand aloft, he used a tool called an aspergillum to lift holy water from a bucket held by an Episcopal priest, the Rev. Stephen R. Harding, another department chaplain.
Monsignor Delendick splashed the water over the wooden rail of the pier with three short, swift flicks of his wrist.
''May you always have calm wind and fair seas,'' he said.

Next, the John D. McKean passed by, then the Governor Alfred E. Smith. Behind the three largest ships were five smaller boats. As each one passed, the monsignor said a blessing and splashed holy water into the harbor.
Then, with all eight of its hoses running full bore, the Fire Fighter drifted back downstream in majestic glory.
As it passed the pier for a second time, one water jet spewed forth cobalt blue, as if by magic. Another ran deep red. The dyed water was offset against an overcast sky.
The other two large ships followed suit, and the East River was soon awash in spray and color. Monsignor Delendick was congratulated, and the bagpipe band struck up a tune.
''You did a good job,'' Salvatore Cassano, the chief of department, told the chaplain. ''None of the boats sunk.''
